DOC.HEAD: Ceausescu Court Poet Saved By the Army From Being Lynched
With AM-Romania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A poet who had described deposed President Nicolae Ceausescu as ``the most beloved son of the Romanian people'' tried to take refuge Monday in the U.S. Embassy to escape a crowd that wanted to lynch him. But army soldiers intervened and took Adrian Paunescu away after embassy personnel would not let him enter, witnesses said. Paunescu, in his mid-40s, for years was responsible for running ``Song to Romania,'' a festival of music and poetry eulogizing Ceausescu and his wife Elena. Ceausescu was overthrown Friday and captured a day later by the army following a popular uprising. The couple was executed Monday, state radio said, after being tried and found guilty of ``grave crimes,'' including the deaths of 60,000 protesters and the plundering of $1 billion in public money. Paunescu, who owns a 10-room villa in downtown Bucharest complete with a swimming pool and sauna, was considered Ceausescu's court poet for many years until he fell into disfavor in 1985, when police reportedly found he was involved in orgies at home and had illegally built an Alpine retreat at Breaza, north of Bucharest. Under Ceausescu, Romanians were allowed to own just one home. When it became apparent that Ceausescu's demotion would be imminent, Paunescu tried to address a rally in the palace square in front of the Communist Party headquarters Friday to criticize the dictator, but was booed by the crowd. In 1973, when bookstores were filled with volumes bearing Ceausescu's picture entitled ``Homage,'' Paunescu said the book was issued ``as a rousing evocation of the reverberations produced in the mind of the Romanian nation by the anniversary of the most beloved son of the Romanian people _ President Nicolae Ceausescu.''
